pros:
There are some awesome people that work at Pima.  Good benefits.
Pima is really the only game in town in terms of affordability for students with limited resources.  There are some great faculty and staff that really care about students.
cons: The problem with Pima is it has some sort of sickness, kind of like a chronic disease that can't be fully cured.  It gets better at times, but it just can't seem to shake the sickness.  What is the sickness....I would call it cultural incompetency and fear, especially at the administrative level.  Administrators making fat 6 figure salaries that don't want to make difficult decisions because they do not want to upset anyone.  Leadership tends not to be around either.  It became common towards the end of my time there for staff to complain that administrators can never be found.  Lack of leadership and leadership presence leaves people feeling uneasy, uncared for and demoralized.  These are the exact symptoms staff exhibited when I eventually decided to leave Pima.  I am very grateful for my 10 years at Pima, but I am so glad to be out of there.

pros: Love the people, great environment
cons: Can get somewhat disorganized at times but what doesnt

job_title: Student Services Specialist in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Friendly Team
Continuing Education Opportunities
Dynamic Covid-19 Response
cons:
Limited Hours & Benefits
Temporary Position

review_title: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.
pros: A lot of paid time off, in the form of generous vacation, sick leave, and a lot of paid holidays. Very cheap classes for employees. Opportunity to meet and interact with a diverse student population.
cons: Anyone can do whatever they want there with no consequences whatsoever beyond a write up (issuance of scratch paper). The lack of accountability produces the chaotic, hostile environment that you can imagine it would. It is this bizarro world where, in most cases, it is the scum that rises to the top rather than the cream. There were good people there who behaved themselves out of personal integrity, but in most cases the bad people are the ones who rose to power there.

pros: Tucson is a laid back town and the students are great!
cons: PCC seems to always be embroiled with scandal among their top leadership.  Department chairs make or break your experience.  The hiring process = nepotism.  Student evals = high stakes but low validity.  Lowest community college pay rate in Arizona.  Each campus is its own world, no congruence between campuses in any respect.  No commitment/support for adjunct faculty.  Outdated technology that usually has problems of some kind (e.g. d2l outage, lack of wifi across entire campus).  Expect to give all students a A b/c if they complain for any reason, your job is jeopardized.  Tucson job market is horrible, so plenty of people are willing to take your job and give students whatever they want in order to keep the (low paid, inconsistent) adjunct contract.

pros: Low stress environment, friendly staff and students, Easily approachable administrators with open door policy.
cons:
Faculty have too much power within the organization, ignoring administrative policies they do not feel like following.  Very little progress or encouragement to implement new or more efficient methods of performing work.  Ideas instantly shot-down by supervisor if it was not the supervisor's idea.

Position was a temp position for over 10 years with multiple positions within the department and at multiple campuses.  Okay if you are a student planning to stay for short length of time.

job_title: Support Specialist At Northwest in Tucson, AZ
pros: Higher education is a critical component of our society.
cons: Beyond the culture of abject incompetence, I have never witnessed a workplace with greater animosity towards its' part time employees. They treat you like nameless cattle. They make it clear that you are "lesser" in every way. Maybe it's to make themselves feel better about how terrible they are at college administration. When the Higher Learning Commission comes around they scramble to put lipstick on a pig, lest they lose their accreditation - something they have had issues with for years. They don't care about their people and the people, in turn, provide terrible customer service to the students. It's a terrible cycle. There is not one person that I've spoken with who enjoys their job or thinks Pima does a good job managing staff. Mostly, everyone has low morale and is totally jaded.

review_title: Adjunct Instructors are second class citizens
pros: Flexibility in choosing schedules and classes.  Enjoyable working with others in the adjunct department and with most managers who understand the important role that adjunct staff plays in the overall success of the college mission.
cons: Adjunct instructors are not recognized as professionals by their "real" (full-time regular) instructor colleagues.  Although many of us have the same or superior qualifications as "real" instructors at the college, we are not treated with the same respect.

review_title: Pima Community College Center for Training and Development
pros:
Playing a part to assist students in the development of real world skills through Pima's Center for Training and Development has been extremely satisfying. I have enjoyed the one on one and continued support we have provided each individual to complete their goals in various medical fields and functional business skills. 

Overall, the college is extremely supportive of their employees with health and wellness benefits and individualized attention if needed.
cons: As it is in any business or institution there have been occasional management styles that have not been functional or productive. Nepotistic practices have been improved, however these practices still exist.

job_title: Faculty Resource Center, Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The people are amazing! I worked with and for some of the best people. I was able to get a quality education as well for practically free! Lots of professional development training and was able to speak my mind and felt respected by my superiors. Benefits are good. The offer a lot of vacation time and every holiday you can think of.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement. I worked there for 12 years and was only able to get a lateral move, not for lack of trying!

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: A great place to work at the functional level. I was treated as a professional and given a lot of autonomy by several department chairs. Great support staff and co-workers. As long as the students did not complain I was left alone.
cons: Typical educational bureaucracy starting at the division dean level. No thought to economy, efficiency, or end result. Focus is on process, procedure and asserting power and dominance in the hierarchy. Ultimately demeaning and dehumanizing. Adjunct is fine, but avoid full time if you can.

review_title: Going to be great in five years
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Work/life balance, benefits, vacation, being there for the communities learning needs. 
Working to help others succeed.
I fully believe that in five years Pima will be a premier learning institution that is student centered.
cons:
Major organizational change needed and currently in development. On probation. Uncertainty.
Employees holding on to old feelings beliefs that have led to the predicament we are in.

pros: Great People to work with!!!
cons: Worked as a TEMPORARY for several (5+) with no benefits!!!!!

review_title: Just when you think things are getting better, they get dramatically worse.
pros:
Interesting, capable, and friendly faculty colleagues.
Hard working and appreciative students, most who are first-generation college students.
PCC is the educational bargain of the state. Such an excellent education for less than $85 a credit hour. You have to wonder why anyone in southern AZ would pay $1500 per credit hour for the UA.
cons:
A truly bloated, overpaid, and unimaginative administration.
Rude staff members who treat adjuncts like the administration trains them to do- like unskilled, lowly paid grunts.
Ask part-timers to do a lot of unpaid work, including more than 15 hours of unpaid mandatory training this year. It's absolutely outrageous, disrespectful, and possibly illegal (at least I assume people are supposed to be paid for being at work).

review_title: Great as a part time job or to fill the resume
pros: Flexibility to a point.  They will try to work with your schedule if you are an Adjunct Faculty.  They provide excellent resources for teaching, especially for those who have not taught before.
cons: Each campus is different.  Be sure to check out the teaching style for your class, department and campus.  Also, no office space for adjuncts so we are forced to carry projects, exams, quizzes home.

pros: Close contact with a wide diversity of students (ethnic/cultural background, age, religion, socioeconomic condition, etc.) and direct impact on their ability to find and apply information for their educational needs is very rewarding.
cons: Community colleges don't usually have the number of resources that a university does and we don't have the variety of coursework.  Course content and degree programs tend to be limited and may not be as stimulating to a librarian or information professional.  Not much opportunity for advancement--such as different classifications of librarian positions.

pros: Able to set my own schedule and my boss has always been very understanding when it comes to needing time off. My coworkers have always been a joy to work around and are quite helpful when they see you struggling.
cons: The pay isn't great and has gotten significantly worse this past year thanks to the minimum wage hike. It really hit the college hard and saw to it that most of us got our hours cut back significantly and now instead of making slightly more than minimum wage we no longer do.

pros: You get a lot of sick leave and vacation time, as well as a lot of paid holidays.  Partially makes up for the below average salary.  Environment is not great but is getting better.
cons: Salaries are currently below average compared to similar institutions.  Environment is not great but is getting better.

pros: Great benefits, skilled and dedicated colleagues, safe, clean, and comfortable work environment.  Progressive thinking and community development opportunities will surround you.
cons: With the Governor's recent budget cuts, and the College's continuing challenges with accreditation and program compliance, the pace and quantity of work are at a high tempo, with frequent resource challenges.

pros: The benefits are great-a lot of vacation time, state retirement plan and flex spending account. Job security is great.
cons: Difficult to advance. Employees tend to stay for a very long time because the benefits and pay are good, but many seem to be unhappy with the culture and politics which creates a negative work environment.  Cuts in staff and the lack of accountability leads to some employees having heavy workloads.

pros: Help and teach students and give them advices regarding their study and future.  prepare some guide papers to the student.
cons: we work hard with many students in one day.  We have to help all the students we have that make the job not easy.

pros: Really big company with a lot of temporary positions. If you are looking for good competitive pay for temporary seasonal work, good place.
cons: No real room for advancement. Every job is under scrutiny for money reasons. A lot of internal politics and gossip between leadership and departments.

job_title: Special Projects Coordinator in Tucson, AZ
pros: The people at PCC are awesome and work tirelessly to serve their students and the community well.
cons: PCC is a large institution with the issues of being large and bureaucratic as well as in the cross hairs of decreased funding from the AZ legislature.

review_title: Great Place, Great Colleagues, Great Students
pros: Love the students, my colleagues, the work environment and location of my campus (West Campus).
cons: I'd like to see more courses in my field (ESL) offered completely online since I'm now qualified to teach them in this mode.

review_title: It was the best of times, worst of times.
pros: Fantastic students with a genuine interest in improving their life opportunities; you will not find a more rewarding experience.
cons: Administration has created an environment of fear.  NW Campus VP openly states that policy does not matter and she will not follow any policies she does not believe in.  Leadership has a practice of simply transferring problem administrators to a different campus.

review_title: I LOVE working for Pima Community College!
pros: Above-average salary for the area, great benefits, some advancement opportunities.
cons: Not as many advacement opportunities as I would like.  Pima Community College is in the newspaper alot lately, even though the media has fabricated most of the headlines.

pros:

- I get a good deal of freedom in my course plan
cons:

- I get no health insurance or other benefits

pros: While the news focuses on budget issues, this institution is focused on student success and making positive changes to enhance serving our community. Kudos for all the progress!
cons: Spread out all over Tucson, it's hard to see the great impact PCC has on our community.
